questions.text: Name the marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor among the following
questions.solution:
• DOG1 and CD117 are the most sensitive markers for GIST.
  • GIST also expresses CD34, SDH,PDGF receptor A.
  • S100 is a marker for melanoma.
  • CA15-3 is a marker for breast cancer.
  • NRG-1 highly expressed in papillary carcinoma thyroid

 Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 607.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Salter Harris type 1 fracture
questions.solution:
• A- Salter Harris type 1 separation through the hypertrophic or calcified zone of the growth plate;
  • B-fracture through a portion of the physis that extends through the metaphysis;
  • C- fracture through a portion of the physis that extends through the epiphysis and into the joint
  • D- fracture across the metaphysis, physis and epiphysis.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 750.

questions.text: Identify the histological type of carcinoma lung
questions.solution:
• Presence of keratin pearls in the given image is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma lung.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma is a type of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).
  • SCC is more strongly associated with smoking than any other type of NSCLC.
  • Squamous cell lung tumors often occur in the central part of the lung or the primary airway, such as the left or right bronchus


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 718-720.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an extra-esophageal complication of GERD?
questions.solution:
• Extra esophageal complications of GERD include -laryngitis dental, erosions, pharyngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, asthma chronic cough, recurrent otitis media.
  • Mechanism of extraesophageal complications of GERD -
  1. Proximal esophageal reflux and micro aspiration of duodenal contents causing injury to larynx and lower respiratory tract;
  2. Second mechanism includes distal esophageal acid exposure causing a reflex vagal reflex leading to bronchospasm and cough.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1114.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Photophobia and lacrimation in a three month old child?
questions.solution:
Congenital cataract is a lens opacity that is present at birth or shortly after birth. Symptoms of the condition include:
  • A gray or white spot on the eye pupil.
  • Pupils that appear white.
  • Blurry vision.
  • Cloudy vision.
  • Double vision.
  • Reduced vision.
  • Colors appear faded.
  • Lights appearing too bright.

Congenital cataract may also cause amblyopia but it seldom produces watering and photophobia among the following options

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 386-387.

  • The given image has a cock and screw appearance, which is typical of diffuse esophageal spasm.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1121-23.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of hypokalemia
questions.solution:
Complications of hypokalemia include:
  • (1) cardiac - tachyarrhythmias, qt prolongation
  • (2) GI- intestinal pseudo-obstruction and constipation,
  • (3) renal- Prolonged hypokalemia can precipitate acute kidney injury, Hypokalemic polyuria due to central polydipsia and an AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect, mimicking nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, interstitial nephritis
  • (4) musculoskeletal system -hypokalemia induces hyperpolarization, compromising the muscle's ability to depolarize and contract effectively leading to weakness and paralysis. Rhabdomyolysis
  • (5) respiratory failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscle
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 349-351.

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in gonorrhea
questions.solution:
Gonorrhoea is unlikely cause of Genital Ulcer
  • Gonorrhoea is caused by a gram negative diplococci- Neisseria gonorrhoea. infection begins in the cervix uteri and urethra and may spread to the Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • The vaginal mucosa is usually unaffected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to cocci infection and also because vaginal secretions have an acidic pH.
  • Complications include: urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, chronic pelvic pain, infertility, first-trimester abortion, and ectopic pregnancy, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, liver capsule inflammation with resultant intra-abdominal adhesions.
  • Complications specific to males include epididymitis, prostatitis, and proctitis, Infections in the periurethral tissues can lead to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).
  • On evaluation of discharge of gram stain shows an intracellular gram negative diplococci. Stuart's transport medium is used. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250 mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose, or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 235-237.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of ventricular cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
• Due to the property of a long refractory period among cardiac muscles, the cardiac muscles cannot be tetanized.
  • Other properties of ventricular cardiac muscle include all or none phenomenon, length tension relationship.


Phases of cardiac action potential
● 0→ Depolarisation and overshoot-Due to opening of voltage-gated Na+ channels
● 1→ Initial rapid repolarization-Due to closure of Na+ channels and opening up of K+ channels
● 2→ Plateau phase - Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
● 3→ Late rapid repolarization
● 4→ Baseline (RMP).

Phases 3 and 4 are due closure of Ca2+ channels and a slow, delayed increase of K+ efflux through K+ channels.
During phases 0 to 2 and about half of phase 3 of cardiac action potential, cardiac muscle cannot be excited again, that is, it is in its absolute refractory period. It remains relatively refractory until phase 4. Thus, cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 112-115.

questions.text: Among the following, identify the second generation, LMA
questions.solution:
(i) Intubating laryngeal mask airway

(ii) Flexible laryngeal mask airway

(iii) LMA fastrach

(iv) Proseal LMA

  • Proseal LMA is a 2nd generation LMA device as it has a separate gastric tube to decompress the stomach and prevent gastric aspiration associated with the classical LMA or 1st generation LMA.
  • Other 2nd generation LMA's include LMA Supreme, I-Gel and LMA Protector.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: Which of the following graphs depict Lineweaver Burk plots uncompetitive enzyme inhibition
questions.solution:
A Lineweaver-Burk plot is a graph that shows the Michaelis-Menten equation of enzyme kinetics.


The plot is made by plotting the reciprocals of the substrate concentration and velocity values on a graph. The x-axis is 1/[S] and the y-axis is 1/V.

Reference: Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page No 63-65.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of methylergotamine
questions.solution:
• Methylergometrine is an ergot derivative, which acts directly on the myometrium.
  • It causes uterine contractions with increasing intensity and frequency such that the uterus passes into a state of spasm without any relaxation in between.
  • Hence, it should only be used either in the late second stage of labor after the delivery of the anterior shoulder) or following the delivery of the baby.
Indications :
● Prophylactic - Active management of the third stage of labor.

● Therapeutic - To stop the atonic uterine bleeding, following delivery, abortion or expulsion of hydatidiform mole.

Contraindications :
● Multiple pregnancy - If given accidentally with the delivery of the first baby, the second baby is compromised by the tetanic contractions of the uterus.
● Heart disease - Results in sudden squeezing of blood from the uterine* circulation into the systemic circulation causing overloading of the right heart and failure.
● Hypertensive disorders, pre-eclampsia and eclampsia
● Rh-negative mother - More risk of fetomaternal microtransfusion.
● Vascular disease

Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 390,468.

questions.text: Which of the following decleration concerns therapeutic abortion
questions.solution:
• Declaration of Oslo refers to therapeutic abortion
  • Declaration of Helenski is concerned with human experimentation.
  • Deceleration of Sydney is on human death: states that determination of death "will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids", such as EEG.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No 493.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the diagnostic criteria of mucocutaneous lymphnode syndrome
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease:
Fever of at least 102.2 F for five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:
1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (90% of cases)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with uterine rupture
questions.solution:
• Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a genetic disorder affecting collagen formation and function. manifests clinically with skin hyperelasticity, hypermobility of joints, atrophic scarring, and fragility of blood vessels.
  • EDS is classified into 6 types (classical, vascular, hypermobile, arthrochalasis, kyphoscoliotic, and dermatosparaxis)
  • Vascular EDS is an autosomal dominant disease with a prevalence of 1–9/100 000. It is most often associated with a mutation in COL3A1 oR, COL1A1, which respectively code for type-III and type-I procollagen chains.
  • Type-III collagen is found in the skin, vessel walls and viscera, where it provides structural robustness.
  • Vascular EDS is one of the most severe disease subgroups because its complications are potentially life-threatening.

The major clinical diagnostic criteria for vascular EDS include the occurrence of spontaneous colon perforation, uterine rupture during pregnancy, in the absence of a previous caesarean section, and/or severe peripartum perineal tears, arterial rupture before the age of 40 years and the formation of a carotid cavernous sinus fistula in the absence of trauma

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 149,507.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR
questions.solution:
• GFR is determined by sum of the hydrostatic and colloid osmotic forces across the glomerular membrane.
  • It is also dependant on Glomerular Kf (glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient). Formula: GFR= Kf[(glomerular hydrostatic pressure- glomerular oncotic pressure)-(bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure- Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure)]

Hence factors that increase GFR include:
(1) increase in glomerular capillary filteration coefficient
(2) increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure
(3)decrease in bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure
(4) decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure .

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 666-667.

questions.text: Which of the following joint is not formed by the bones in the following image
questions.solution:
The given image of a thoracic vertebra participates in the following joints.
1. Intervertebral joint - secondary cartilaginous joint ( symphysis type )
2. Costovertebral joint - plane synovial joint
3. costotransverse joint - plane synovial joint
4. Facet joints or zygopophysial joints - synovial joint.
5. Syndesmosis which is type of complex fibrous joint




between two bones connected by ligaments and a strong membrane and allows little movement. In the vertebra syndesmosis is formed by anterior and posterior ligaments

Synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint and allows no moment at the joint example: first sternocostal joint

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: A 50 year old man was brought to the emergency with chest discomfort and palpitations on evaluation patient was unconscious, diaphoretic with a pulse of 158bpm BP 80/40mmhg ecg showed narrow complex tachycardia what is the next best step in management
questions.solution:
As the given patient with PSVT is hemodynamically unstable the next line of management would be synchronised cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. They mainly present with dizziness and palpitations.

When the patient is hemodynamically stable:
● Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if a prior history of stroke is seen
● Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
● Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It.can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence, it must be used with great caution in such patients.
● Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e., hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1895-1898.

questions.text: The mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve receives which of the following sensations
questions.solution:
• The trigeminal nerve has three branches the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions.
  • The first-order neurons for each division originate from trigeminal ganglion also known as gasserion ganglion.
  • These first-order neurons carry sensory information from the face to the brainstem. Upon entering the brainstem, the fibers synapse with second-order neurons in specific nuclei:
1. Principal Sensory Nucleus (Main Sensory Nucleus):
-Receives input from all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve and is Located in the pons.
-Second-order neurons here carry discriminative touch and proprioceptive information.
2. Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus (Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal):
-Receives input mainly from the maxillary and mandibular divisions.
-It is Located in the medulla.
-Second-order neurons here carry pain and temperature sensations. Other trigeminal nerve nuclei

1. Mesenephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve -located in the brainstem, near the periaqueductal gray and lateral to the cerebral aqueduct.
- It is the only structure in the central nervous system to contain the cell bodies of first-order sensory neurons. Neurons in this nucleus are pseudounipolar and receive proprioceptive afferent information from the mandible.
- They send efferent projections to the trigeminal motor nucleus to mediate monosynaptic jaw jerk reflexes.

2. Motor nucleus of trigeminal nerve
The Trigeminal Motor Nucleus refers to a region located in the dorsolateral pontine tegmentum that is responsible for controlling the muscles involved in jaw movement. It differs from other motor nuclei in that it receives inhibitory input from mechanoreceptors and free nerve endings, which compensates for its unique organization. This nucleus plays a crucial role in speech control, mastication, and can contribute to masticatory myofascial pains.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 453-454.

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented with breathlessness and chest pain following a viral illness. On examination patient had a pulse rate of 110bpm BP of 100/60 on auscultation normal vesicular breath sounds were present with no added sounds which of the following is not seen in this condition.
questions.solution:
• The given image shows water bottle sign seen in massive pericardial effusion following a viral illness.
  • Clinical features include Becks triad that is muffled heart sounds, hypotension, jugular venous distension.
  • Other physical exam findings unique to pericardial effusion include the Ewart sign, characterized by dullness to percussion at the base of the left inferior scapular border, tubular breath sounds, and egophony.
  • Patients with pericardial effusion demonstrate Pulsus paradoxus that is drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration. This drop occurs because the expanding right ventricle collapses the left ventricle, causing the interventricular septum to bow and compress the left heart, leading to decreased filling, reduced stroke volume, and lower systolic blood pressure.
  • Several tests can help evaluate a suspected pericardial effusion. On a chest radiograph The heart may appear boot-shaped in the presence of significant, chronic effusion or a "water bottle sign" may be seen.
  • ECG findings be normal or have non-specific ST-segment changes for small effusions. The ECG may demonstrate electrical alternans for large effusions or tamponade, which is a specific but not sensitive finding.
  • On echocardiogram Right atrial free-wall collapse or inversion during systole, right ventricular free-wall collapse during diastole, increased septal bowing into the left ventricle during inspiration and the right ventricle during exhalation may be seen.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2019-2020.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be detected by FISH?
questions.solution:
• Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is a method of molecular analysis of genetic lesions involving large deletions, duplications, or more complex rearrangements that are not detectable by PCR.
  • It is not useful for identifying point mutation.
  • Point mutations are identified by other means like sequencing studies and restriction fragment length polymorphism.
  • FISH uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. To perform FISH, large fragments of cloned genomic DNA spanning up to 200 kb are labeled with fluorescent dyes and applied to metaphase chromosome preparations or interphase nuclei.
  • The probe hybridizes to its homologous genomic sequence and thus labels a specific chromosomal region that can be visualized under a fluorescent microscope.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 182-183.

questions.text: Which of the following micronutrient deficiency is associated with hypogonadism
questions.solution:
• Zinc deficiency causes decreased sexual maturation and hypogonadism.
  • Other features of zinc deficiency include (1) Poor physical growth (2) anemia (3) anorexia (3) alopecia (4) impaired immune function
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder of severe zinc deficiency, caused by impaired intestinal absorption due to a defect in intestinal zinc transporter protein.
  • It presents in early infancy with vesiculobullous, dry, scaly, or eczematous skin lesions chiefly in the periorificial and acral areas.
Reference: Prasad AS, Mantzoros CS, Beck FW, Hess JW, Brewer GJ. Zinc status and serum testosterone levels of healthy adults. Nutrition. 1996 May;12(5):344-8. doi: 10.1016/s0899-9007(96)80058-x. PMID: 8875519.

questions.text: As per WHO mental health gap action plan which of the following is not a priority condition?
questions.solution:

  1. Depression,
  2. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders,
  3. Suicide,
  4. Epilepsy,
  5. Dementia,
  6. Disorders due to use of alcohol, disorders due to use of illicit drugs, and
  7. Mental disorders in children.
Reference: 
mhGAP: Mental Health Gap Action Programme: Scaling Up Care for Mental, Neurological and Substance Use Disorders. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2008. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK310851/

questions.text: What is the antibiotic of choice in a patient with enterococcal endocarditis with penicillin resistance ?
questions.solution:
Enterococci is a hospital-acquired pathogens, producing infections like:
● Urinary tract infections
● Bacteremia and mitral valve endocarditis (in intravenous drug abusers)
● Intrabdominal, pelvic and soft tissue infections
● Late-onset neonatal meningitis and sepsis.
  • Frequently Strains resistant to penicillin and other antibiotics are seen. In case of high-level resistance, the choice of drug is vancomycin.
  • In case of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) linezolid, streptogramins (active against E.faecium, but not to E.faecalis) and daptomycin are used
In infections caused due to E. faecalis ampicillin is used as a first-line antibiotic and resistance is rare.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1201.

questions.text: Which of the following is not in relation to the anterior horn of lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
The anterior horn of the lateral ventricle extends from the genu of the corpus callosum up to the interventricular foramen. The relations of the anterior horn are:
● Anteriorly - Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
● Roof - Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum
● Floor and lateral wall - Caudate nucleus
● Medial wall - Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix.

Thalamus is in relation with the floor of the body of lateral ventricle.


Fig: A horizontal section of the cerebrum dissected to remove the roofs of the lateral ventricles.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 272.

Prolonged aPTT and factor VIII as treatment

questions.text: What are the hematological abnormalities seen haemophilia B and what is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Blood product contents present indication
Fresh frozen plasma all coagulation factors, plasma proteins, protein C &S, Antithrombin bleeding disorders in which the missing clotting factor is unknown or when the specific clotting factor is not available
Cryoprecipitate fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, and von Willebrand factor haemophilia A, von willebrand disease, DIC
Cryodepleted plasma supernatant plasma left after the removal of cryoprecipitate from fresh frozen plasma
contains most clotting factors in similar amounts to FFP but is deficient in factor VIII, fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, factor XIII and fibronectin.		  used as an alternative to FFP for the treatment of coagulopathy where there is no significant reduction in Factor VIII, fibrinogen, Factor XIII or VWF such as Hemophilla - A
for rapid temporary warfarin reversal in patients requiring emergency surgery and in warfarin overdose with life-threatening bleeding
 
  • Hemophilia B, also known as Christmas Disease, occurs due to a deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas Factor. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)contains all coagulation factors, including factor IX, and can be used to treat Hemophilia B, and cryo poor plasma is the plasma remaining after the cryoprecipitate has been removed, and it still contains factor IX, making it useful for treating Hemophilia B.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 669.

choices.text: Percutaneous endoscopic gastronomy (PEG) used for gastric outlet obstruction
Percutaneous endoscopic gastronomy used as a first step in the treatment of complex orofacial malignancies for nutrition of the patient.
Flatus tube for the treatment of sigmoid volvulus

questions.text: Name the following instrument and its use
questions.solution:
The given image shows percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy.
  • The insertion of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube improves nutritional and functional outcomes in patients who cannot maintain oral nutritional intake.
  • PEG insertion is often a preliminary step in the treatment of complex orofacial malignancies and can also be used to support nutrition in patients with various malignant, degenerative, or inflammatory diseases.
  • Contraindications to percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement, include coagulation disorders, bowel obstruction, infection, severe ascites, peritoneal carcinomatosis.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 151.

questions.text: Which is the Ideal maintainable fluid of choice in children
questions.solution:
5% dextrose and Normal saline(DNS) is the ideal maintenance fluid in children.Hypotonic fluids increase the risk of hyponatremia, hence Isotonic fluids(like normal saline) with 5% dextrose are recommended as standard maintenance fluid except in neonates.5% dextrose provides 17 calories/100 mL and nearly 20% of the daily caloric needs.


Note: #controversial - Till 2010's - ideal maintenance fluid in children used to be considered as 1/2 NS + 5%D. However, recent research in AIIMS/PGIMER Chandigarh and MAMC concluded that isotonic fluids like NS + 5% D should be preferred over 1/2NS + 5% due to increased risk of hyponatremia with hypotonic fluids. Hence, option (2) >> Option(1).  The answer has been confirmed after checking with Pediatrics Professor Dr Rakesh Lodha at AIIMS, New Delhi. 

(Answer might be given as N/2 +5%D in non updated Q-banks and by old faculty who are not updated with new research and guidelines)


Reference:
1. Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 426.
2.0.45% Versus 0.9% Saline in 5% Dextrose as Maintenance Fluids in Children Admitted With Acute Illness: A Randomized Control Trial. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/36040464/

questions.text: What is the benefit of ER screening in breast cancer?
questions.solution:
• Estrogen receptor (ER) is used as a prognostic marker.
  • Prognostic marker generally is used to describe molecular markers that predict disease-free survival, disease- specific survival, and overall survival.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 1047-1051.

questions.text: Which of the following is a weak estrogen derivative?
questions.solution:
• Estriol is a weak estrogen derivative.
  • There are three estrogens that are present in significant quantities in humans—beta- estradiol, estrone, and estriol.
  • Beta estradiol is secreted by ovaries. It is 80 times more potent than Estriol.
  • Estriol is an oxidative product derived from both estradiol and estrone, the conversion occurs mainly in the liver.
  • Estrone is formed in peripheral tissues from androgens secreted by the adrenal cortices and by ovarian thecal cells.
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page No 364.

questions.text: A 30 year old male working in a chemical factory presented with red eyes lacrimation and burning sensation. What is the first line of management in the given case?
questions.solution:
• Steps in management of chemical burns to eye:
  • Initial step involves immediate and thorough irrigation with the clean water or normal saline.
  • Topical antibiotic drops to prevent infection.
  • Steroid eye drops to decrease inflammation, neutrophil infiltration, and treat anterior uveitis. It is advised to avoid use after 2 weeks, as steroids could disrupt collagen synthesis.
  • Cycloplegics, such as atropine, to enhance comfort.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 457-458.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the diagnostic criteria for diabetic ketoacidosis
questions.solution:
To establish the diagnosis of DKA, three of the following components should be present:
1) elevated plasma glucose (>250 mg/dL),
2) the presence of ketones (in serum or urine), and
3) presence of acidosis (serum bicarbonate <18 mEq/L and/or arterial pH <7.30)
4) anion gap [calculated as Sodium - (chloride + bicarbonate)]should be elevated.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3115.

questions.text: Which of the following is a heme breakdown product?
questions.solution:
• Main products of heme degradation include billiverdin, carbon monoxide, iron.
  • Heme breakdown occurs over a series of reactions. Heme is degraded by microsomal heme oxygenase.
  • It requires NADPH and cytochrome c. In this process, the alpha methenyl bridge of the heme molecule is liberated as carbon monoxide. The Fe+ liberated is oxidized to Fe3+++ and taken up by transferrin.
  • Biliverdin (green pigment) is released during heme breakdown which is further reduced to bilirubin (red-yellow pigment) by an NADPH-dependent biliverdin reductase.
  • The bilirubin is bound to albumin in the blood and is taken up by the liver, where it is conjugated with glucuronic acid to make it water-soluble, which is then excreted in the bile.
  • Bile reaches the intestine and intestinal bacteria deconjugate the bilirubin, which is reduced to urobilinogen. It is further reduced to stercobilinogen, which is excreted through feces.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 321-322.

questions.text: Which of the following OHA increases the risk of urinary tract infections?
questions.solution:
• SGLT2 inhibitors such as dapagliflozin are known to cause UTI inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter which is present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule and is responsible for the reabsorption of 80-90% of filtered glucose.
  • This results in glycosuria. common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine.
  • There is also a risk of the developing diabetic ketoacidosis.
  • Benefits include weight reduction and BP lowering action.
  • It has also shown benefits in management of heart failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 301.

questions.text: A 40 year old male who is a known case of chronic kidney disease presented with history of recurrent kidney stones, altered sensorium and abdominal pain. On evaluation he had low serum calcium levels with elevated parathyroid hormone. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above history is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy. it is a complex condition caused by the inability to maintain normal calcium and phosphorus levels in the blood.
  • In chronic kidney disease, vitamin D is not converted into its active form. Hence calcium absorption in the intestine is impaired, thus causing decrease, calcium levels.
  • This decrease in calcium level stimulates the parathyroid gland to secrete PTH in order to increase calcium absorption. This elevated PTH known as secondary hyperparathyroidism causes increased bone resorption to release calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream, leading to bone pain and fragility, and contributing to the formation of kidney stones due to the elevated phosphate and calcium levels in the urine.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2313-2316.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
• The given image is suggestive of hypercortisolism- Cushing's syndrome
  • Cushings disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome which occurs due to Pitutary corticotrope adenoma.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2959-2965.

questions.text: Which of drugs used in the treatment of leprosy causes skin pigmentation
questions.solution:
• Clofazamine is a component of mutidrug treatment in management of leprosy. It a drug with leprostatic and antiinflammatory properties.
  • The mechanism of antimicrobial activity of clofazimine against mycobacteria appears to be multifactorial and includes membrane disruption, inhibition of mycobacterial phospholipase A2, inhibition of microbial K+ transport, generation of hydrogen peroxide, interference with the bacterial electron transport chain, and efflux pump inhibition.
  • Adverse effects include
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances-Clofazimine can cause nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. These side effects can be severe and may require a change in dose or stopping the drug.
  • Skin discoloration-A reddish-orange color from the drug can cause skin and bodily fluids to turn pinkish-brown. This discoloration can affect the face, eyes, sweat, urine, tears, and stools. It can be especially noticeable in fair-skinned patients who are exposed to light. The discoloration may fade after stopping the drug.
  • Arrhythmia : Clofazimine can cause an irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No 833.

questions.text: Name the hormone produced from zone A and zone C
questions.solution:
Layers of adrenal gland are as follows;
● Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells. Secretes mineralocorticoids
● Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial
columns. Secretes corticosteroids
● Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells. Secretes androgens.
● Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells. Secretes catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine.



Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 331.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of Teriparatide?
questions.solution:
• Teriparatide is a parathormone analog, administered subcutaneously.
  • Dose being 20mcg once daily into the thigh or abdomen.
  • Teriparatide and abaloparatide (PTHrP analog) are the only anabolic agents currently available that increase new bone formation .
  • Adverse effects include hypercalcemia, exacerbation of nephrolithiasis, elevation of serum uric acid levels and increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. Hence not to prescribed for more than 2 years.
  • Ostenecrosis of Jaw is associated with Bisphosphonates
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 789.

questions.text: A 17 year old female presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination she normal secondary sexual characteristics, breast development corresponding to tanner stage IV. Endocrine evaluation revealed normal levels of FSH, LH. And she had a 46XX karyotype. What could be the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The given patient shows features suggestive of mullerian agenesis.
  • It is the congenial absence of both the uterus and vagina termed as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome. Clinical features include. :
  1. Shallow vaginal pouch (1 to 2 inches deep).
  2. Uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina are absent.
  3. These patients have normal ovaries persist, as they originate from the genital ridge.
  4. Normal secondary sexual characters. -46XX karyotype.
  5. Other features: kidney abnormalities- horseshoe kidney, skeletal abnormalities
Reference: William’s Gynecology, 4th Edition, Page No 421.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
• Most common sites to be involved in Hodgkin's lymphoma are cervical and clavicular lymph nodes.
  • Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma with good prognosis and presents as a mediastinal mass in young patients.
  • Reed sternberg cells are of B cell origin and are positive for CD 30 and PAX5 markers.

questions.text: The following image on a background of alkaline ph is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
• Coffin lid shaped crystals are suggestive of triple phosphate stones.
  • They are also known as staghorn or struvite stones. It is usually caused due to infection with urea-splitting organisms, such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia, or Enterobacter species.
  • Urea metabolism by these organisms lead to formation of an alkaline urine and precipitation of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate - resulting in the formation of struvite stones.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1474-75.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
• Mutations in tRNA are known to suppress the mutant gene and cause reversal to wild phenotype. Such mutations are called suppressor mutations
  • Suppressor mutations are secondary mutations that alter the phenotypes caused by an existing mutation. suppressor mutations return the phenotype caused by the original mutation to a more wild-type phenotype despite the presence of the original mutation.
  • The suppressor mutation's effect on the phenotype can vary from partial restoration to full restoration of the wild-type phenotype.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 409-410.

questions.text: Which of the following sexually transmitted diseases is associated with drug resistance?
questions.solution:
• Gonorrhoea is caused by Neisseria gonnorrhea. These gonococci have the ability to develop complete resistance to antibiotics either by chromosomal mutation or by acquiring R factors.
Mechanism of resistance:
  • B-Lactamase producing Gonococci and tetracycline-resistant strains occur together. Hence Penicillin, ampicillin, and tetracycline are no longer effective against Neisseria Gonnorrhoea.
  • Changes in DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV cause fluoroquinolone resistance.
  • Drug efflux pump and reduced drug influx also contribute to resistance against cephalosporins.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1124,1128.

pH being <7.35 is suggestive of acidosis and pco2 being >45 is suggestive of a respiratory cause of acidosis

choices.text: Neuroblastoma is the second most common primary abdominal tumour of childhood
Most common presentation of Wilms tumour is an abdominal mass
Mean age of presentation of Wilms tumour is five years of age

questions.text: Which of the following is false?
questions.solution:
• Neuroblastoma is the most common primary abdominal malignancy in children followed by Wilm's tumor, while Wilm's tumor itself is the most common primary malignant renal tumor children less than 5 years of age.
  • Wilms tumor commonly presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass.
  • Other findings of Wilm's tumor include hypertension, abdominal pain, gross painless hematuria, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and weight loss.
  • CECT abdomen is used to identify the extent of the tumor, integrity of the other kidney, and metastasis.
  • Wilms tumor is metabolically active and can concentrate fluorodeoxyglucose therefore PET/CT is also helpful to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions.
  • Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done as treatment for Wilm's tumor. Nephron-sparing nephrectomy is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney.
  • Chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine and dactinomycin with the addition of Adriamycin(Doxorubicin).
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 262.

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following organs except
questions.solution:
• Erythropoietin is secreted by interstitial cells in the peri-tubular capillary bed of the kidneys and by perivenous hepatocytes in the liver.
  • It is also generated in the brain, where it provides a safeguarding effect against excitotoxic harm caused by hypoxia; and in the uterus and oviducts, where it is stimulated by estrogen and seems to facilitate estrogen-driven angiogenesis.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 696.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Her-2 inhibitor monoclonal antibody?
questions.solution:
• Pertuzumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody directed against HER2.
  • It approved for the treatment of patients with HER2-positive, locally advanced, inflammatory, or early-stage breast cancer in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel.
  • Its adverse effect includes cardiotoxicity.
  • Cetuximab, Panitumumab, Necitumumab act against epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)/ HER-1.
Reference: Katzung basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 972.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reversal agent for non depolarising muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Answer: Both Sugammadex (Option 1) and Neostigmine (Option 4) are reversal agents for non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. However, Sugammadex is more specific for aminosteroid muscle relaxants.

Explanation:

Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., Rocuronium, Vecuronium, Atracurium) work by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Their reversal is achieved by increasing acetylcholine levels or directly binding the relaxant.

  1. Sugammadex (Option 1) – Most effective and selective

    • Specifically binds to aminosteroid non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (Rocuronium, Vecuronium), rapidly reversing their effect.
    • Acts via encapsulation, preventing the drug from blocking acetylcholine receptors.
    • Fast and effective, with fewer side effects compared to cholinesterase inhibitors.

  2. Neostigmine (Option 4) – Indirect reversal agent

    • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor → Increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, outcompeting the muscle relaxant.
    • Used for both aminosteroid (Rocuronium, Vecuronium) and benzylisoquinolinium (Atracurium, Cisatracurium) relaxants.
    • Administered with Glycopyrrolate (Option 2) to counteract muscarinic side effects (bradycardia, secretions).
To choose between two Suggamadex is an better answer

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 851.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites reproduce via parthenogenesis?
questions.solution:
• Females of Strongyloides stercoralis are known to be parthenogenetic i.e. capable of generating offspring without the need for fertilisation by a male.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis has a parasitic cycle and a free-living cycle in soil.
  • Humans are the natural host. Filariform larvae are the infective form and there are two modes of infection: penetration of the skin by 3rd stage filariform larva, and autoinfection. female worms present in the intestine lay eggs in the mucosa which hatches immediately, releasing the rhabditiform larva.
  • The larva migrates into the lumen of the intestine and passes down to be released into the faeces. The rhabditiform larva may change into a filariform larva while passing through the bowel.
  • The filariform larvae in the bowel do not leave the host and become a source of autoinfection as they penetrate the colonic mucosa or perianal Skin. The rhabditiform larvae passed in the faeces may undergo two types of development in the soil:

1. Direct development: The rhabditiform larva moults twice on reaching the soil to become the infective filariform larva. The filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.
2. Indirect development: The rhabditiform larvae develop into free-living males and females in the soil.

Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 169,115.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with chest pain, palpitations since the past 1 hour. On evaluation his ECG is as follows. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG is suggestive on posteroinferior wall MI. It shows ST elevation in inferior leads and ST depression in leads V1 V2 V3.
  • The ECG findings of an acute posterior wall MI include the following:
  • ST segment depression (not elevation) in the septal and anterior precordial leads (V1-V4). This occurs because these ECG leads will see the MI backwards; the leads are placed anteriorly, but the myocardial injury is posterior.
  • A R/S wave ratio greater than 1 in leads V1 or V2.
  • ST elevation in the posterior leads of a posterior ECG (leads V7-V9). Suspicion for a posterior MI must remain high, especially if inferior ST segment elevation is also present.
  • Posterior wall MI is typically caused by occlusion of the circumflex artery or the posterior descending artery, which supplies the posterior aspect of the heart.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2053-2055.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations is not possible in case of twin pregnancies
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 16 year old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain. On evaluation it was found that she hasn't attained menarche . On local examination a tense bluish mass was seen per vagina. What could be the possible diagnosis
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of post translational modification?
questions.solution:
• Glycosylation is a post- translational modification.
  • Protein post translational modifications (PTMs) refer to the breaking or generation of covalent bonds on the backbones or amino acid side chains of proteins and expand the diversity of proteins.
  • To date, more than 650 types of protein modifications, such as the most well-known phosphorylation, ubiquitination, glycosylation, methylation, SUMOylation, short-chain and long-chain acylation modifications, redox modifications, and irreversible modifications, have been described.
Options B,C,D are examples of post transcriptional modification.

Reference: Vasudevan textbook of Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page No 572,584.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare cause of bilateral pedal edema
questions.solution:
• Lower extremity edema is the accumulation of fluid in the tissues of the legs, leading to swelling. It can result from various conditions affecting the circulatory, lymphatic, or renal systems.
  • Bilateral pedal edema is usually caused due to fluid retention or decreased serum albumin levels.
  • In Chronic venous insufficiency veins in the legs do not efficiently return blood to the heart, leading to pooling of blood and fluid leakage into surrounding tissues.
  • However, this edema is usually unilateral depending on the limb that is affected.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 275-78.

questions.text: Which is the best test used for detection of malarial infection and to estimate parasite concentration?
questions.solution:
• Malarial parasite detection and parasite quantification is best done by a Giemsa-stained thick smear.
  • Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due high sensitivity and specificity. A diluted Giemsa stain is applied to both thick and thin films.
  • Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium.
  • Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, Page No 306.

questions.text:
Assertion(A): Late trophoblast and schizont stage in Plasmodium falciparum are not seen in blood smears.
Reason(R): These two stages are trapped in the capillary endothelium of internal organs due to cytoadherence.
questions.solution:
• Late trophozoite, early and mature schizonts are stages in the asexual life cycle of P.falciparum.
  • These stages are usually not seen in the peripheral smear unless the malaria is exceptionally severe or pernicious. ,
  • In regular conditions these two stages are trapped in the capillary endothelium of internal organs due to cytoadherence.
Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 80-81.

questions.text: Which of the following features is incorrectly matched with the disease?
questions.solution:
• Immunodeficient individuals lack the normal response to antigens. Hence no reaction seen on contact with antigen. Example - False negative Mantoux test.
  • Chickenpox infection on microscopy shows cytopathic effect of formation of multinucleated giant cells, with rounding and ballooning of infected cells.
  • Berylliosis causes chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease similar to sarcoidosis and Biopsy reveals non-caseating granulomas with monocytic infiltration.

Syphillis presents with the following lesions :

● Primary syphilis - Hard chance, which is painless papule that becomes eroded and indurated.
● Secondary Syphilis - Skin rashes on palms and soles which may be macular, papular, papulosquamous and nodular, but never vesicular or bullous.
● Condylomata lata- mucocutaneous papules that coalesce to form large pink to grey lesions in warm moist intertriginous areas
● Generalized lymphadenopathy is seen
● Tertiary Syphilis - Gummas, which are locally destructive granulomatous lesions.

Reference: Essentials of Microbiology, 3rd edition, Page No 757 ,758.

questions.text: A 39 year old lady came with alleged history of rodenticide consumption. On examination patient had an irregular pulse, quadriparesis present. Lab investigations revealed severe hypokalemia. Name the active ingredient present in this poison
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario can be caused be Barium carbonate used in rat poison.
  • Barium carbonate is a local corrosive irritant that, after absorption, mainly acts on muscles including the heart muscles.
  • Initial symptoms include intense gastrointestinal distress, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Subsequently, muscle cramps and stiffness, pupil dilation, tongue and larynx paralysis, and vertigo occur.
  • Severe CNS manifestations include loss of reflexes and paralysis. Early impacts on the heart lead to elevated blood pressure, a slow and irregular pulse, and potential cardiac arrest in systole.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 33rd Edition, Page No 548-549.

questions.text: Condition causing Difference in the refractive power between two eyes is called ?
questions.solution:
• Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal.
  • A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated.
  • Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 44-45.

questions.text: Which of the following lab sterilising techniques is used to sterilise a disposable pipette?
questions.solution:
Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Beta propiolactone/ formaldehyde Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
lonising radiation Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters,grafts

Autoclave is the most effective method to sterilise disposable pipette tips. Autoclaving involves subjecting the pipette tips to high-pressure steam at temperatures above 121°C (250°F) for around 20 minutes.

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker textbook of Microbiology, 8th edition, Page No 30-38.

questions.text: What is the trauma code in triage for patients who are critical and likely to survive if treatment initiated within few hours?
questions.solution:
The internationally accepted four-color coded system is used commonly.
It includes:
● Red - High priority attention or transfer; Critical, but likely to survive if treatment is given early
● Yellow - Medium priority; Critical, likely to survive if treatment is given within hours
● Green - Ambulatory patients; Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
● Black - Dead or moribund patients; Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 449.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma?

● Parasitic infections- Opisthorchis viverrini, C. sinensis
● Congenital - Choledochal cysts, Caroli's disease
● Chemical agents- Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast), Vinyl chloride,
Dioxin, Asbestos

questions.text: What is the best line of management for a patient parenting with sudden onset unilateral LMN facial palsy with normal imaging findings?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy.
  • Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days.
  • Acyclovir can also be used in patients who are suspected to have exposure to the herpes virus.
  • Tape or eye masks to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3439-3441.

questions.text: In the quadruple marker test, a 33 year-old G2P1L1 at 18 weeks of gestation was found to be at a high risk of neural tube defects and low risk of trisomy 21. What is the next investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
For a female with a quadruple test showing a low risk of trisomy 21, the next investigation to be done is an anomaly scan, as part of routine antenatal care.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 339.

questions.text: A young male presented with low GCS of 10 following a fall from height on evaluation found to have anisocoria with the following CT image. What is the best line of management?

questions.text: A young female presented to the ER with anaphylaxis. Which of the following is not a part of the criteria for diagnosis of anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis is characterised by hypoptension caused by the sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen.

questions.text: A patient who underwent thyroidectomy developed Hoarseness of voice following surgery. Which of the following steps in surgery could not have resulted in this complication?
questions.solution:
• Hoarseness of voice post thyroidectomy can be due to injury to external laryngeal nerve or unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • Division of strap muscles during thyroidectomy is a step where its least likely for the nerve injury to take place.
  • During thyroidectomy external laryngeal nerve injury is more common than recurrent laryngeal nerve and presents with hoarseness of voice.
  • At times bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury can occur causing dyspnea needing emergency tracheostomy however voice remains normal.
Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 851-852.

questions.text: What is the best line of management for a patient above 65 years of age presenting with intracapsular neck of femur fracture?
questions.solution:
• In patients over 65 years old with an intracapsular neck of femur fracture and a normal hip otherwise, hemiarthroplasty is the standard management approach.
  • Reduction and fixation of fractures in the elderly patient is not recommended due to the associated high rates of subsequent reoperation, non-union and osteonecrosis of the femoral head.
Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 5th Edition, Page No 135.

choices.text: it is the investigation of choice for gallstones

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CT scan?
questions.solution:
• On CT, each image consists of a matrix of data points (pixels) that are assigned a number that represents the X-ray attenuation(y) at that point in the body. CT number is a scaled version of u that is normalised to the X-ray attenuation of water (pW).
CT = 1000 × (X ray attenuation/pW - 1)
The resulting numbers are called 'Hounsfield units' (HU).

CT numbers assigned to various parts that are scanned are:
● Water = 0 HU
● Solid soft tissues are centred around 0 HU
● Lungs = -1000 HU
● Air = -1000 HU
● Dense cortical bone = +1000 HU
● Acute Blood Clot = 60-90 HU
● Fat = -100 HU

Reference: Grainger and Allison Diagnostic Radiology, 6th Edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: Give below is an image of an excision biopsy performed on a neck swelling, what is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is a cross-section of a lymph node, showing caseating granuloma with Langerhan's giant cells. Th response is responsible for the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis.

Other options provided do not typically show caseous necrosis.

choices.text: Rapid cyclers are more common in women

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Rapid cyclers?
questions.solution:
• Rapid cycling disorder is diagnosed when the patient has a combination of 4 or more bipolar episodes within the last 12 months.
  • Two separate episodes can be demarcated from one another by either switch in polarity or full/partial remission for at least 2 months.
  • Possible risk factors for rapid cycling disorder include female patients, diabetes, childhood abuse or family trauma, and alcoholism or substance abuse.
  • The drug of choice for prophylaxis of rapid cycling disorder is Valproate.
