questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding ABO blood grouping?
questions.solution:
• With regard to ABO blood grouping Antibodies are required following birth from 2 to 8 months of age.
  • The A and B antigens are complex oligosaccharides that differ in their terminal sugar. The agglutinins are gamma globulins produced by the bone marrow and lymph gland cells.
  • Most of them are IgM and IgG immunoglobulin molecules.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 552-53.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to prevent breast engorgement and pain in the mother following death of the neonate?
questions.solution:
• Dopamine regulates prolactin secretion in the body.
  • Dopamine released from the hypothalamus into the hypophyseal portal blood supply acts on lactotroph D2 receptors to decrease prolactin secretion.
  • Hence DA agonists like bromocriptine and cabergoline are used in conditions requiring suppression of prolactin.
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 679.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of proptosis in middle aged individuals?
questions.solution:
• Graves ophthalmopathy is one of the most serious ocular manifestations of Graves disease.
  • Between the ages of 25 and 50, it's the leading cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults.
  • The mechanism proposed for this is the acute precipitation of a hypothyroid state which leads to an increase in TSH secretion.
  • This leads to stimulation of the retro-orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes which have the receptor for TSH.
Reference: Parson Disease of the eye, 23rd edition, Page No 1165.

choices.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is required while using lepirudin

questions.text: Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
• Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which is a recombinant form of hirudin extracted from the saliva of leech.
  • It is administered parenterally and the Mode of action is independent of anti-thrombin, I.e it can reach and inactivate fibrin-bound thrombin in thrombi.
  • Dabigatrin is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor.
  • Enoxaparin is a LMWH and does not need monitoring
  • Fondaparinux  binds to antithrombin resulting in inactivation of Factor Xa.
Reference: Katzung Basic and clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 617.

choices.text: Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in otitis media with effusion
Otoscopy shows loss of light reflex of tympanic membrane
Characterized by the accumulation of purulent serous effusion in the middle ear cleft
usually occurs following an episode of common cold

questions.text: All of the following are features of otitis media with effusion EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
• Serous otitis media also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear.
  • Type B tympanometry curve is obtained in otitis media with effusion
  • Hearing test- Rinne negative suggestive of Conductive hearing loss
  • Impediance audiometry - Flat curve
  • Otoscopy shows loss of light reflex of tympanic membrane
  • Treatment is aimed at removal of fluid and preventing recurrence


Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 75-77.

questions.text: Which among the following is not part of the Beck's cognitive theory on depression?
questions.solution:
• Introjection is not a part of Beck's cognitive theory of depression
Becks Cognitive triad consists of
  1. Beliefs about oneself
  2. Perceptions of surrounding
  3. Thoughts about future


Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 354-55.

choices.text: Normal or low calcium low phosphorus levels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
• Initially, low calcium levels in the blood stimulate increased PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands that results in bone resorption and increased reabsorption of calcium and increased excretion of phosphorus in the kidneys.
  • Hence blood calcium levels can be low to normal with low phosphorus evels and high ALP due to increased bone resorption activity.
  • Due to increased PTH secretion there is low urine calcium excretion and high urinary phosphate excretion are seen.
Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 113.

questions.text: OHA of choice in a diabetic with echo showing reduced ejection fraction
questions.solution:
• Dapagliflozin, which is a sodium-glucose transporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor used for diabetes has been recently approved for use in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and is the preferred drug in this patients with diabetes and heart failure.
  • Dapagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT-2) in the proximal renal tubules resulting in reduced reabsorption and increased urinary excretion of glucose.
  • Dapagliflozin acts as a diuretic and natriuretic by reducing sodium and volume load, causing intravascular contraction.
Other beneficial effects of dapagliflozin
(1) Blood pressure reduction.
(2) weight loss

Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 261 ,763.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria and progression of renal damage?
questions.solution:
The following drugs are beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors / Angiotensin receptor blockers - These medications appear to slow the rate of decline of kidney function by reducing the intraglomerular hyperfiltration and hypertension.
  • Finerenone - It is a non steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist which decreases proteinuria.
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors - These drugs inhibit sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 in the proximal convoluted tubule. By increasing Nacl delivery to the thick ascending limb, gliflozins trigger tubuloglomerular feedback and thereby increase preglomerular vascular resistance and decrease glomerular hypertension. This contributes to the effectiveness of gliflozins to prevent diabetic kidney disease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2316, 2319.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions are known to cause wheals?
questions.solution:
• Urticaria is a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by itchy wheals, which develop due to evanescent edema of dermis.
  • A wheal is a transient, well-demarcated, superficial pink or pale swellings of the dermis due to reversible exudation of plasma in the skin that fade, usually within hours, without leaving a mark.
  • Wheals are usually very itchy and associated with a surrounding red flare when they arise.
Porokeratosis, Tinea corporis and Pityriasis rosea are known to cause annular lesions.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 65.67.

questions.text: Which is the most common hernia in females?
questions.solution:
The most common hernia in females is an indirect inguinal hernia.
Inguinal hernia is the most common hernia in men and women. It is classified into :
● Indirect hernia - protrusion of the contents occurs through the deep inguinal ring, along with the spermatic cord, lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. It is the most common subtype of groin hernia in both males and females.
● Direct inguinal hernia - Occurs through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal through the Hasselbach's triangle. The sac is medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

Reference: Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, Page No 1599 .

choices.text: A- somatostatin B- GHRH C- GH D- IGF1
A- GHRH B- somatostatin C- GH D- IGF1
A- GHRH B-GH C- somatostatin D- IGF1
A- GHRH B-IGF1 C- GH D- Somatostatin

questions.text: Identify the hormones marked in the image given below
questions.solution:
The flow chart shows the regulation of growth hormone secretion.
● GHRH secreted from the hypothalamus acts on the anterior pituitary to release growth hormone.
● The released GH increases the circulating levels of IGF-1 which exerts its effect on the tissues.
● Somatostatin secreted from the hypothalamus is an inhibitory effect on the GH secretion from the anterior pituitary.
● IGF -1 exerts negative feedback on GH secretion and positive feedback on somatostatin secretion, which in turn inhibits GH secretion.

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 319.

questions.text: which of the following is not a feature of Korsakoff's psychosis?
questions.solution:
• Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by the lack of thiamine (vitamin B1).
  • The disorder includes Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff amnesic syndrome which are not different conditions but different stages of the same disease (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome).
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy represents the "acute" phase of the disorder and Korsakoff's amnesic syndrome represents the disorder progressing to a "chronic" or long-lasting stage.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy includes ataxia, opthalmoplegia, dementia.
  • Korsakoff's psychosis includes Amnesia, polyneuropathy and confabulation.

Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 632.

questions.text: Which of the following causes a decrease in serum parathyroid hormone?
questions.solution:
• Lithium can increase PTH secretion by affecting calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands.
  • The active form of vitamin D, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), directly suppresses PTH gene expression
  • Calcitriol is the active form of vitamin D. It increases calcium absorption from the intestines and helps maintain adequate serum calcium levels.
  • When calcium levels rise, this triggers a negative feedback mechanism on the parathyroid glands, leading to decreased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • PTH's raises blood calcium levels, so when calcium is sufficient, the need for PTH decreases, resulting in lower PTH levels.
  • Risedronate is a bisphosphonate that inhibits bone resorption, but it doesn't directly affect PTH secretion.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 1052,1059.

choices.text: Febrile seizures can have post ictal neurological deficit
Simple febrile seizures occur in children between six months to 5 years of age.
Anticonvulsants prophylaxis is usually not indicated in simple febrile seizures
Simple febrile seizures do not last for more than 15 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Option (1) is a False statement.

Febrile seizures are seizures that
  1. Occur in children between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  2. Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  3. Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  4. Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  5. Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.
Hence, option (1) is a false statement.

Other options

Option (2) - True - febrile seizures are seizure which occur post fever as a trigger in children between 6months - 5 years. 

Option (3) - True - simple febrile seizure do not require anti-convulsant prophylaxis in most cases. Intermittent prophylaxis with clobazam is indicated in few cases if (a) febrile seizures are too frequent (>3 episodes in 6 months/>4 episodes in 12 months),(b) if there is excessive parental anxiety or (c) if the first episode occurred in a child less than 12 month. 

Option(4) - True - simple febrile seizures last for less than 15 minutes, are GTCS in nature and do not reoccur with 24 hr of first seizure. 

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page No 3092-3094.

questions.text: Which of the following is transmitted by all the components of blood?
questions.solution:
• Malaria is the only disease transmitted by all components of blood.
  • Bite of infected Anopheles mosquitoes, inject sporozoites into the bloodstream and is capable of causing infection.
  • Hence malaria can be caused by transfusion of sporozite infested blood.



Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 80.

questions.text: A young female presented with complaints of pain in the abdomen and bleeding PV for the last 2 days. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks back. On examination, she has hypotension, tachycardia and cervical motion tenderness. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows free fluid in the pouch of Douglas and paracolic gutters. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario with a triad of abdominal pain, amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding, along with the ultrasound findings of free fluid, is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • An ectopic pregnancy is one in which the fertilized ovum is implanted and develops outside the normal endometrial cavity, with the Fallopian tubes being the most common site.
  • The outcomes of such a pregnancy are varied with tubal rupture and massive intraperitoneal hemorrhage being one of them.
  • Treatment- Resuscitation and Laparotomy
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 171.

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of secondary survey in trauma management?
questions.solution:
• CT head is a part of secondary survey in trauma management.

Indications for CT head following trauma are.

-CT scan of the head is to be performed within 1 hour if the GCS is <14 at the initial assessment.

- patient has a tense fontanelle, or a possibility of an open/ depressed or base of skull fracture, abnormal pupillary response, abnormal posturing, and a focal neurological defect.

- patient has three or more vomiting episodes, a witnessed loss of consciousness or amnesia for >5 minutes.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 273-275.

choices.text: Increased levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid
Folate deficiency is commonly seen in children with hemolytic anemia
Periconceptional folate supplements, begin 3 months before conception and continued for 1 month after conception to reduce neural tube defects
It is important to treat co-existing vitamin B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Folic acid plays a key role in one-carbon metabolism, essential for the biosynthesis of several compounds.
  • Tetrahydrofolate (THF), the reduced, coenzyme form of folate, receives one-carbon fragments from donors such as serine, glycine, and histidine and transfers them to intermediates in the synthesis of amino acids, purine nucleotides, and thymidine monophosphate.
  • Folate deficiency is caused by increased demand (e.g., pregnancy and lactation), poor absorption caused by pathology of the small intestine, alcoholism, or treatment with drugs (e.g., methotrexate) that are dihydrofolate reductase inhibitors. It is seen in children with macrocytic anemia.

Folate deficiency causes
(1)Anemia -due to diminished synthesis of purine nucleotides and TMP, which leads to an inability of cells to make DNA and, therefore, an inability to divide.
(2)Neural tube defects : in order to prevent these defects Peri-conceptional folate supplements is begun 1 month before conception and continued for 3 months after.
(3) Hyperhomocysteinemia - Folate, along with vitamin B12, is involved in converting homocysteine to methionine. Hence folate deficiency causes increased levels of homocysteine.

Reference: Vasudevan textbook of Biochemistry, 8th Edition, Page No 475-479.

choices.text: Faucial diphtheria can cause death due to myocarditis
Corynebacterium diphtheria causes myocarditis due to bacteremia.
Patient can develop dyspnea due to obstruction secondary to pseudomembrane formation
Bull's neck appearance is due to cervical lymphadenitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false
questions.solution:
Diptheria is caused by Corynebacterium diptheriae. This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane.
Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis
Complications of C. diphtheriae:
● damage to the heart (myocarditis)
● kidney (tubular necrosis)
● liver and adrenal glands can be affected due to the toxin
In respiratory diphtheria patients, cardiac complications, particularly myocarditis, arise in around 10-25% of cases.
Myocarditis caused us due to the toxins released causing toxaemia.
Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death in Diptheria

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 240-242.

choices.text: Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery
Injection labetolol , antenatal steroids, and immediate termination of pregnancy
Injection labetalol and magnesium sulphate and deliver at 37 weeks
Injection labetalol to control her blood pressure

questions.text: A 34 year old primigravida with chronic hypertension came to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation with headache and blurring vision. Her BP is 180110 mm Hg. Urine analysis reveals urine albumin 3+. What is the next step to be done?
questions.solution:
In case of chronic hypertension with superimposed severe pre-eclampsia, the next step of management is to give injection labatelol and magnesium sulphate and expedite the delivery irrespective of the duration of gestation.

Criteria for diagnosis of superimposed pre-eclampsia are.

-Aggravation of hypertension
-Development of HELLP syndrome. -New onset proteinuria.
-Development of headache, scotoma, and epigastric pain.

Conditions where pregnancy is terminated regardless of the period of gestation:
● Uncontrolled severe hypertension
● Eclampsia
● Pulmonary edema
● HELLP Syndrome
● Renal dysfunction
● Coagulopathy (disseminated intravascular coagulation)
● Abruption
● Fetal compromise

Reference: William’s Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page No 690,716.

questions.text: Label the given histopathological cross section of epiphyseal cartilage which contains rapidly dividing chondrocytes
questions.solution:
B Rapidly Proliferating layer

Epiphyseal cartilage is divided into five zones :
  • ● The resting zone consists of hyaline cartilage without morphological changes in the cells.
  • Proliferative zone consists of chondrocytes that divide rapidly and form columns of stacked cells parallel to the long axis of the bone.
  • The hypertrophic cartilage zone contains large chondrocytes whose cytoplasm has accumulated glycogen. -calcified cartilage zone is formed by the death of Chondrocytes and the thin septa of cartilage matrix become calcified by the deposit of hydroxyapatite.
  • The ossification zone contains endochondral bone tissue
Reference: Amizuka N, Hasegawa T, Oda K, Luiz de Freitas PH, Hoshi K, Li M, Ozawa H. Histology of epiphyseal cartilage calcification and endochondral ossification. Front Biosci (Elite Ed). 2012 Jan 1;4(6):2085-100. doi: 10.2741/e526. PMID: 22202021.

choices.text: Start IV pantoprazole and antiemetics stabilise the patient with IV fluids, electrolyte correction
Order a liver biopsy to assess fibrosis

questions.text: What is the first line of management in a chronic alcoholic having chronic liver disease, presenting with altered mental status and Hematemesis?
questions.solution:
The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:
● Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection(intubation to protect airway and prevent aspiration), and oxygen
● Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
● Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy .
● An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
● Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
● Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
● In case, of failure or rebleeding - Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1168,1204.

questions.text: 35 year old male with high myopia suddenly presented with history of flashes of light and left eye, what could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario of a patient with severe myopia, experiencing sudden flashes of light the likely cause could be retinal detachment.
  • Retinal detachment is the separation of the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
  • Examination findings- RAPD, Altered red reflex, Vitreous pigment on anterior vitreous (Shaffer sign), Shifting fluid sign.
Risk factors include
  • myopia,
  • previous intraocular surgery such as aphakia or pseudophakia,
  • a family history of retinal detachment, and
  • trauma.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 309-313.

choices.text: Tetanospasmin released by the bacteria causes presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Extoxin A released by the bacteria causes inhibition of acetyl choline release
Exotoxin released by the causative agent causes increased release of glycine and GABA neurotransmitter

questions.text: Following injury by a rusted iron nail a construction worker presented with a locked jaw, muscle rigidity. Which of the following is the mechanism for this presentation?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of a locked jaw and rigidity with a background history of injury from a rusted nail is suggestive of a diagnosis of tetanus.
  • The toxin responsible for muscle rigidity and lockjaw is Tetanospasmin.
  • It acts by causing presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 264-268.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication to start corticosteroids in a patient with IgA vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Indications for steroids in IgA vasculitis/Henoch Schonlein Purpura are as follows
- Intractable abdominal pain.
-gastrointestinal bleed
-Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis/ cresentic glomerulonephritis.

Patients usually present with  - Palpable Purpura +Arthralgia + GI manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, intestinal perforation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2814.

questions.text: What is the rate of increase in head circumference in the first 3 months of life?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option(2) 2 cm/month.

When a child is born - At birth, the head circumference(HC) is 33-34cm. 

Head circumference(HC) after birth Grows at the following rate:
 
  • 2 cm/month in first 3 months (option 2)
  • 1 cm/month in the next 3 months
  • 0.5 cm/month in the next 6 months.
At 1 year, HC is 46 cm. At 2 years - head circumference is 48cm (90% of adult HC). As an adult - the HC is 52-53cm. 





Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 12-14.

choices.text: Rare finding in a morphologically, normal heart
Treated with intravenous digoxin to control ventricular rate
Should be treated with cardioversion in all cases
This arrhythmia is seen in holiday heart syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the arrhythmia in the following ECG?
questions.solution:
• The following ECG, is that of atrial fibrillation.
  • Cardioversion, whether electrical or pharmacological, is not always appropriate for every patient with AF.
  • The decision to perform cardioversion depends on several factors, including the duration of the AF episode, the presence of underlying heart disease, the patient's symptoms, and the risk of thromboembolism.
  • In some cases, rate control and anticoagulation may be the preferred treatment
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1903 , 1907-1908.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme deficiency causes maple syrup urine disease?
questions.solution:
• Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency results in maple syrup urine disease.
  • There is defective oxidative decarboxylation of leucine, isoleucine and valine. The disease is characterized by feeding problems, ketoacidosis, changes in muscle tone, and coma.

Other options:
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency causes congenital lactic acidosis.
  • Defective transketolase is a rare disorder of pentose phosphate metabolism causing developmental, intellectual disability, delayed or absent speech, short stature, and congenital heart defects.
  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the TCA cycle which converts isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. Defects in this enzyme are linked to carcinogenesis.
Reference: Hassan SA, Gupta V. Maple Syrup Urine Disease. [Updated 2024 Mar 3]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557773/

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency diseases predisposes to infection by catalase-positive organisms?
questions.solution:
• Chronic granulomatous disease is an X linked recessive disease where Phagocytes cannot efficiently produce reactive oxygen species(ROS), which are crucial for destroying pathogens engulfed by these cells.
  • Reduced hydrogen peroxide (H202) production is the primary cause of the impaired bactericidal function.
  • Other mechanisms contributing to the disease process include Failure of leucocyte degranulation after phagocytosis, leading to delayed granule rupture and faulty release of myeloperoxidase further contributes to ineffective bactericidal activity.
  • Chronic granulomatous disease predisposes individuals to infection by catalase-positive organisms most commonly S. aureus.
  • This disease manifests itself as chronic suppurative granulomatous lesions of the skin and lymph nodes, along with hepatosplenomegaly, progressive lung infilterates and granulomatous septic osteomyelitis.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 117-118.

questions.text: Diagnose the following x-ray
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows fracture of scaphoid bone.
  • Scaphoid fractures account for 70-80% of all carpal bone fractures.
  • Although they occur essentially at any age, adolescents and young adults are most commonly affected.
  • Patients will typically present with pain around the dorsal wrist and/or the anatomical snuffbox after a fall on an outstretched hand
Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page No 115.

choices.text: Cola colored urine in the first two hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in delayed haemolytic transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
• Cola-colored urine in the first 2 hours is a feature of acute haemolytic transfusion reaction.
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions (DHTR) occur days to weeks after a blood transfusion. delayed immune response is often due to the formation of alloantibodies against minor antigens on the donor red blood cells.
  • Clinically, DHTR presents with symptoms such as a failure of rise in hemoglobin levels despite transfusion, increased levels of indirect bilirubin, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, indicative of ongoing hemolysis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 671-672.

choices.text: Conjunctival congestion with follicles, papillary hyperplasia and progressive pannus

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in leprosy affecting the eyes?
questions.solution:
Leprosy can cause lagopthalmos I.e inability to close the eyelids due to environment of zygomatic branch facial nerve. Decreased corneal sensation seen in leprosy is due to the involvement of ophthalmic branch of trigeminal nerve.

Other features seen are:
● Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
● Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
● Miosis
● Iris atrophy
● Iris pearls
● Retinal pearls.

Lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge and foreign body sensation.

Conjunctival congestion, follicles papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features of trachoma

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: All of the following, are actions of inferior oblique, except:
questions.solution:
Intorsion is an action of superior oblique muscle, and NOT of Inferior oblique

Actions carried out by inferior oblique are:
  1. Primary action- extorsion
  2. Secondary action-elevation
  3. Tertiary action- abduction


Reference: Parsons Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 355.

questions.text: Which of the following acts by suicide inhibition?
questions.solution:
• Suicide inhibition is when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme and then undergoes a reaction to form an irreversible complex with the enzyme, inactivating it permanently.
  • Such a mechanism is seen in benzbromarone a uricosuric agent used to treat gout by increasing uric acid excretion.
  • It inhibits CYP2C9 via mechanism-based on (suicide) inhibition.
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 47,1255.

Leavator veli palitini and Superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: The Ischieal spine corresponds to which Vertebral level in Normal Anatomical position

questions.text: Which among the following options does not hold true for some dehydration in a child?

  1. Increased Thirst,

choices.text: Lies Lateral to root of brachial plexus in neck
Left Phrenic nerve lies posterior to thoracic duct
At root of neck lies anterior to second part of Subclavian artery

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding Phrenic Nerve?
questions.solution:
• All the above statements are true Except 2nd statement- It lies Medial to trunk of Brachial plexus in the neck
  •  Phrenic nerve orginates Cervical nerves C3-C5
  • Mixed Nerve
Course of Left Phrenic nerve
  • Neck- Lies Medial to trunk of Brachial Plexus, at the root of the neck it runs anterior to 2nd part of Subclavian artery and posterior to Subclavian Vein.
  • Thorax- Crosses medially in front of Internal Thoracic artery . Within the thorax nerve enters the thorax by crossing medially in front of the internal thoracic artery . Within the thorax the phrenic nerve descends anterior to pulmonary Hilus between the fibrous pericardium and mediastinal pleura.

questions.text: Identify the blood supply of the marked structure ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is Interventricular Septum.

Blood Supply to the Interventricular Septum

  • Posterior One third - Posterior Interventricular artery. Posterior Interventricular artery is branch of Right Coronary Artery.

Reference Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 1089.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong about Rota Virus Vaccine
questions.solution:
• Rota Virus Vaccine is not a subunit Vaccine.
  • It is Oral Live Attenuated vaccine available as Monovalent and Pentavalent forms.
  • According to CDC guidelines Rotavirus should not be given beyond 8 months of age
  • Rotarix (Monovalent) - 2 oral doses at gap of 4 weeks not later than 24 weeks
  • Rotateq (Pentavalent) - 3 doses at 2,4 and 6 months. All doses before 32 weeks
  • Rotavac ( Monovalent Liquid Frozen) - 3 oral doses 4 weeks apart at 6,10 and 14 weeks.
Reference: Park’s textbook of preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page No 270.

questions.text: Mount Fuji Sign is seen in
questions.solution:
• Mount Fuji Sign is seen in Tension Pneumocephalus.
  • Mount Fuji sign refers to the presence of air between the tips of frontal lobes giving it the appearence of Mount Fuji.
Reference: Ryan J, Shields G, Finegan E, Moughty A. Post Traumatic Tension Pneumocephalus: The Mount Fuji Sign. Ir Med J. 2017 Apr 10;110(4):550. PMID: 28665089.

questions.text: Which of the following Structures passes through the Space of Larry
questions.solution:
• The Space of Larry is an opening seen in the Diaphragm through which the Superior Epigastric artery passes.
  • It is also known as the Costo Xiphoid Gap.








Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition, Page No 1039,1020.

questions.text: 25y old male with previous history of RTA to the same limb now came with Pain. The X ray is given below. The likely diagnosis is

choices.text: Hyperacute rejection is mediated by Preformed Antibodies specific for antigens
Acute Rejection is mediated by B cells

questions.text: Which of the statements given below is false?

  • Except for Identical twins, Immunosuppresive therapy is indicated in all kidney transplant patients

questions.text: Which is the most common site for osteoporotic fracture?
questions.solution:

  • Fracture of the distal radius is the most common to occur followed by vertbral body and hip.
  • IOC- DEXA scan

Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 136-140.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of Oxygen delivery to newborn Baby is not suitable?
questions.solution:
• Self inflating bags are not used for Free flow oxygen delivery.

Effective ventilation can be confirmed by

  • Capnography shows exhaled C02
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse Oximeter shows improved saturation.

questions.text: Which of the following blood group can be given to a patient who came to the ER with Severe bleeding and unable to get matching group from the blood bank?
questions.solution:
• O negative is universal donor for all patients because it lacks A B and Rh Antigens on surface of RBC thus minimising adverse reactions.
  • Both O positive and Negative can be used for immediate transfusion with specific considerations. O neg is universal Donor because it lacks A , B and Rh antigens.
  • O pos can be used in emergencies but preferred for transfusing Rh positive patients.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 671, 672.

questions.text: 30y old female was evaluated for sudden onset hoarseness of voice and Difficulty in breathing. She was found to have a mass compressing the trachea from the outside. Biopsy of the mass showed Cells arranegd in nests with Amyloid Deposits. What is the origin of these cells?
questions.solution:
• Clinical scenario and with biopsy showing cells arranged in nest with amyloid deposits is suggestive of Medullary Carcinoma Thyroid.
  • MCT arises from the Parafollicular C cells.
  • Diagnosis is by clinical examination and Raised Calcitonin and CEA along with FNAC of the mass.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 870, 871.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical manifestation of Parvovirus B19 infection?
questions.solution:

  2. Arthropathy,
  3. Aplastic crisis,
  4. Pure red cell aplasia and
  5. Hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: A 30y old male with history of Renal transplant on treatment now came with history of multiple epsidoes of watery diarrhoea. The stool microscopy revealed oocyst of size 30 X15 microns given below. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Given history with Pink Oocyst of size 30 microns is suggestive of Isospora.
  • Isospora causes a self limiting but protracted diarhoea more commonly seen in HIV individuals.
  • Infection is acquired by ingestion of mature oocysts in food or drink.
  • The oocyst can be classified based on the size of the oocyst.

Reference: Panikar’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page No 104.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Voricanazole?
questions.solution:
All the other statements are true except the second one.

questions.text: A 15y old male presents with unilateral Nasal Obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis for the past six months. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: 50y old male comes to the ER with stab wound over right chest. Below is the X ray of the individual. Most likely diagnosis is?

questions.text: All are true about Renal tubular acidosis in children except?

questions.text: Which of the following is not recommended in an 8y old child with Bilateral SNHL?

questions.text: Which of the following drugs given below is a PCSK -9 Inhibitor?
questions.solution:
• PCSK- 9 causes Lysosomal degradation of LDL receptors hence reducing LDL uptake.
  • PCSK-9 inhibitors prevents this degradation hence increasing LDL uptake. Eg- Alirocumab and Evolocumab.
  • Bempedoic acid- Prevents de novo cholesterol Synthesis

  • Ezetimibe-Inhibts Luminal cholesterol uptake
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th Edition, Page No 740.

questions.text: All the following are components of High Quality CPR , Except?
questions.solution:
• Option 2 is wrong statement.
  • Depth of compression should be atleast 5cm.
  • Rest of the options are components of high Quality CPR.
  • Other components include to
  1. place the patient with face up on firm and flat surface.

  4. Allow complete chest recoil
  5. Compression:Ventilation is 30:2

questions.text: A 20 day old baby presented with history of altered sensorium with neck rigidity and vesicular lesions over the face and body. The mother had history of painful Genital Ulcers in the past. CSF study revealed Multi nucleate giant cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.text: A 28y old female at 40 weeks of Gestation is in the Second stage of labor for the last two hours.PV- Head is at +3 station and adequate contractions. The suture is in AP diameter and Caput is present. which is thr most appropriate mode of delivery?
questions.solution:

  1. Scalp visible at Introitus ,
  2. Fetal skull has reached Pelvic floor,
  3. Saggital suture in AP direction but rotation <45 degrees,

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable sign of some dehydration in severe acute malnutrition?

questions.text: 75y old female came to the ortho OPD was diagnosed with and undisplaced Extra Capsular neck of femur Fracture. What is the best line of management?

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agents is safe to use in renal failure patients?

questions.text: A 35y old male with history of sore throat was treated with course of oral antibiotics. Patient now came to the OPD with facial puffiness and periorbital edema. URE showed esopinophilia and WBC casts. The most likely diagnosis is

questions.text: Which of the following is not a red flag sign is patient presenting with headache?

Cocaine abuse with headache can lead to Hypertensive Emergencies or strokes but not considered a primary red flag sign.

questions.text: Which of the following does not diffferentiate between necrosis and Apoptosis?

questions.text: All the following antidotes are used to treat Cyanide toxicity, Except?

questions.text: Which of the following cavities is opened first in case of fetal autopsy?

questions.text:

questions.text:

questions.text: 27y old female presented with proximal one third fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice?

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not a criteria to Diagnose IUGR?

questions.text: Which of the following is a nuclear neuroendocrine immuno Histochemical marker?

questions.text: Inhaled nitric oxide is used for?

questions.text:
The anthropometry of a 5y old is as follows.
Weight for height:  -1.2SD,
Height for age :  -2.5 SD,
Weight for Age :  -2.7 SD.
According to WHO criteria, what does the child have?
questions.solution:
According to WHO criteria, since H/A is less than -2SD but W/H is normal (between +2 to -2SD) the diagnosis of this child is Chronic Malnutrition. (option 1) 

Note:  Weight for age(W/A) is also below -2SD in the example - that would make the child "underweight" - but it is not in options. Remember, acute malnutrition is defined using low Weight for length ( W/L <-2SD) while chronic malnutrition is defined using low Height for age (H/A <-2SD). Weight for age is not used in definition of either and a child with low W/A is simply called underweight.  

Below is the table with classification of Malnutrition.



Other options
 
  • Option 2 - Only H/A is low, W/L is normal - hence child does not have acute on chronic malnutrition.
  • Option 3 -  W/L is normal ( between +2SD and -2SD) - hence child does not have acute malnutrition
  • Option 4 - W/L is normal ( between +2SD and -2SD) - hence child does not have acute malnutrition

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 334.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Retinitis Pigmentosa

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of infection of the organism given below?

questions.text: In which of the scenario given below will you administer Post Partum Anti D prophylaxis in woman whose Blood group is O negative and Husband's blood group is B positive?
questions.solution:
• Post Partum prophylaxis is given if Baby is O positive and DCT negative.
  • Anti D immunoglbulin should be administered within 72 hours.
  • This reduces alloimmunisation by 90%.
  • The mode of action is antibody mediated Immune suppression.
  • Anti D is futile if Baby is Rh negative- there is no risk of alloimmunisation or if DCT is positive- alloimmunisation has already taken place.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 314.

questions.text: 15 y old child presents with short stature. His Upper segment/Lower segment ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Normal U:L segment ratio in child >7 y is more than 1.
  • Causes for Low U:L ratio -
  1. Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia,
  2. Marfan syndrome,
  3. Vertebral anomalies.
  • High U:L ratio cause-
  1. Rickets,
  2. Achondroplasia,
  3. Turner,
  4. Congenital hypothyroidism.
Reference: Ghai essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 32.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to test the blood taken from a neonate for metabolic disease screening?
questions.solution:
• Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is a technology used to screen for and diagnose metabolic disorders such as amino acid disorders, urea cycle disorders, organic acid disorders, and fatty acid oxidation disorders in newborns and infants.
  • Mass spectroscopy identifies molecules based on their mass or molecular size. The sample is vaporized such that a positive charge is produced on the molecule. An electric field is applied so that particles move.
  • At the same time, a magnetic field is applied, so the cations are deflected and hit on the detector. For molecules of identical charge, the time required for the molecule to reach the detector is inversely proportional to the mass of the molecule.
  • In tandem mass spectrometry, two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially. The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, the parent ion can be directed into the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller jons. These daughter ions are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 31.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic with respiratory acidosis

questions.text: ABG findings of a person presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting are as follows. pH 7.30, HCO3-18, Na 135, K+ 5, Cl- 92. Blood glucose is 490 mg/dL. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
• As the pH in the given ABG is less than 7.35 it is acidotic with and bicarb of 18 is suggestive of metabolic acidosis.
  • The anion gap of the given ABG is 135- (92+18)=25 which is greater than 12 and is suggestive of high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Anion gap is given by the following formula Anion gap = Serum [Na+ – (Cl– + HCO3–)]




Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 359, 367.

questions.text: What would be the MRI finding in a child with spastic diplegia?
questions.solution:
• Spastic diplegia is commonly seen in premature infants with a history of birth asphyxia.
  • It is second most common type of cerebral palsy in india after spastic quadriplegia.
  • Brain MRI shows scarring and shrinkage in the periventricular white matter with compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles, called periventricular leukomalacia.
  • Multicystic encephalomalacia is the MRI finding seen in children with spastic quadriplegia.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 3169.

questions.text:
A 9 year boy comes with sexual maturity rating 5, height for age > chronological age, hyperpigmentation and short stature. His blood pressure measured 200/110mmHg.
Which of the following enzymes deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
• 11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency is a variant of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) causing increased aldosterone and testosterone activity with reduced cortisol levels.
  • The given clinical scenario of precocious puberty(SMR grading of 5 in a 9 year old boy) with height age> chronological age with short stature and increased blood pressure 180/110 suggests 11 beta hydroxylase deficient variant of CAH.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 2972,2976-77.

questions.text: The following is the most common pathogenic organism for neonatal sepsis?
questions.solution:
• S. agalactiae belonging to Group B streptococci are the most common cause of meningitis and neonatal sepsis followed by E. coli.
Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1087-88.

questions.text: Which of the following is the antenatal dose of steroids for lung maturity?
questions.solution:
• Maternal administration of corticosteroids is indicated when the pregnancy is less than 34 weeks.
  • Either betamethasone 12 mg IM 24 hours apart for two doses or
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IM every 12 hours for 4 doses is given.
  • This is beneficial when the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose. The benefit persists as long as 18 days.
Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page No 296.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is used in the management of cerebral aneurysm?
questions.solution:
• Coiling is the radiological intervention used in the management of cerebral aneurysm.
  • Stenting is used in cases of ICA stenosis.
  • Clipping of aneurysm is generally preferred for ruptured aneurysms.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3355.

Match the following
1.Hepatitis C virus A.Double stranded DNA virus

choices.text: Tail of Spence extends across anterior axillary fold
The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
Vertically, the breast extends from the first to the fifth ribs.
The suspensory ligaments of coopers ligaments are found in the superior part of the breast

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the breast?
questions.solution:
• The breasts are paired structures located on the anterior thoracic wall, in the pectoral region. The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
  • It is divided into four quadrants, i.e upper medial, upper lateral, lower medial and lower lateral.
  • Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs.
  • Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line.
  • A small extension of the upper lateral quadrant, called the axillary tail of Spence, passes through an opening in the deep fascia and extends across the anterior axillary fold extends across the anterior axillary fold.
  • Fibrous strands or sheets consisting of condensations of connective tissue extend between the posterior lamina of the superficial fascia and the dermis.
  • These suspensory ligaments (retinacula or Cooper's ligaments) are often well-developed in the superior parts of the breast and support the breast tissue, helping to minimize drooping.
  • The breasts normally comprise up to 20 discrete lobes that contain ductal-glandular tissue consisting of branching ducts and terminal secretory lobules in a connective tissue stroma.
  • Each lobe is derived by branching from one central lactiferous duct in the nipple, The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU or lobule) is the functional milk secretory component of the breast.
Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 1013.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following leads to familial dysbetalipoproteinemia or type Ill hyperlipoproteinemia ?
questions.solution:
• Defects in apo-E lead to type Ill hyperlipoproteinemia / familial dysbetalipoproteinemia.
  • It is characterized by defective clearance of chylomicron remnants and intermediate-density lipoproteins by the liver
  • This leads to hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis.
  • Defective apo-C Il results in type I hyperlipoproteinemia/ familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency.
  • Familial hypercholesterolemia occurs due to a defect in the LDL receptor.
Reference: Harpar’s illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page No 268.
Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3140-3141.

choices.text: Therapy related MDS is not dependent on age
Patients with MDS are at high risk for developing acute lymphoid leukaemia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Myelodysplastic syndrome is more commonly seen in males.
  • It is a heterogeneous group of hematologic disorders characterized by both cytopenias due to bone marrow failure and a high risk of development of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • MDS is mainly seen in elderly mean age of onset being 70years.
  • Secondary or therapy related MDS is not age related.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 799.

questions.text: A middle aged lady underwent a left parotidectomy. Post surgery she complains of left lower lip paralysis. Which structure is involved?
questions.solution:
• Lower lip paralysis is caused by damage to the main trunk of the facial nerve.
  • The muscles responsible for the movements of the lower lips include the depressor anguli oris and depressor labii inferioris.
  • Both of these muscles are supplied by the marginal branch of the facial nerve, and here the most likely lesion to cause this injury would be an injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve.

The terminal branches emerge from the parotid gland and diverge to supply the various facial muscles as follows :
● Temporal - frontalis, auricular muscles, orbicularis oculi
● Zygomatic — orbicutaris oculi (lower eyelid part)
● Buccal — muscles of the cheek and upper lip
● Marginal mandibular — muscles of the lower lip
● Cervical — platysma

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 1464- 1465.

choices.text: Pond/ indented fracture caused by a wooden stick
Depressed skull fracture caused by a hammer

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture and the weapon used to inflict it
questions.solution:
• Depressed fracture is caused by a heavy weapon or object. In this the striking surface of the weapon is small. E.g. Hammer.
  • Small striking surfaces will cause depression and the pattern of fracture tells about the weapon.
  • It is also known as a signature fracture or signature ala fracture. In this the outer surface is destroyed as well as the inner part is destroyed.
Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Dr. K.S.N. Reddy, 35th Edition, Page No 224,226,230.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical variation in the given CT
questions.solution:
The CT finding in the image is suggestive of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

An aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA) is a rare congenital abnormality of the aortic arch that occurs when the right subclavian artery originates from the aortic arch instead of the brachiocephalic artery.

Course: The artery then runs behind the esophagus to reach the right side. Symptoms: About 30% of patients with ARSA experience symptoms, such as dysphagia, cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. However, most patients are asymptomatic.






Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page No 877.

choices.text: Person with cognitive decline and physical symptoms
Patient with acute psychiatric illness along with crisis
Patient with severe chronic disease and ego dysfunctioning
Person who has good motivation and control over frustration

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for expressive psychotherapy?
questions.solution:
• Expressive psychotherapy and supportive psychotherapy are both types of therapy that can help patients, but they have different goals and techniques:
  • Supportive psychotherapy: it's is indicated for those patients in whom classic psychoanalysis or insight-oriented psychoanalytic psychotherapy is typically contraindicated- those who have poor ego strength and whose potential for decompensation is high.
  • Supportive psychotherapy plays a major etiological emphasis on external rather than intrapsychic events. particularly on stressful environmental and interpersonal influences on a severely damaged self.
  • The general aim of supportive treatment is the amelioration or relief of symptoms through behavioral or environmental restructuring within the existing psychic framework. This often means helping the patient to adapt better to problems and to live more comfortably with his or her psychopathology.
  • Expressive psychotherapy:  is indicated for patients with good motivation and control over frustration.
  • This type of therapy helps patients express themselves and cope with issues like depression, anxiety, and stress. Expressive therapy techniques include creative methods like art, dance, music, drama, and writing. The goal is to help patients learn to regulate emotions, develop social skills, and manage behaviors
Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 850- 852.

questions.text: INSURE is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• INSURE stands for intubate-intratracheal surfactant administration-extubation and is performed in new borns with respiratory distress especially in preterm where surfactant production is reduced.
  • Indications include neonates who are not maintaining oxygen saturation >90% while breathing 40-70% FiO, in nasal CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure).
  • Extubation back to nasal CPAP is done immediately once the infant is stable, usually within minutes to <1 hr of surfactant administration.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 20th Edition, Page No 934.

questions.text: Which is the second most common cause of vision loss due to retinal vascular disease?
questions.solution:
• Retinal vein occlusion (RVO) is the second most common cause of vision loss from retinal vascular disease, following diabetic retinopathy.
  • There are two types of RVO: central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) and Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO).
  • Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) is caused by blockage of one of the tributaries of the central retinal vein. It's characterized by dilated and tortuous veins, flame-shaped and dot and blot hemorrhages, and retinal edema.
  • BRVO is more common than CRVO. Some of the risk factors for BRVO are old age, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, smoking, obesity and hypercoagulable states.
  • Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)- An occlusion of the main retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve.
  • It's typically caused by thrombosis and appears similarly to BRVO, but with hemorrhage in all quadrants of the retina with macular edema.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 280.

questions.text: A young male presents with high grade fever, petechia , vomiting, retro orbital pain and myalgia since 4 days is suspected to have dengue hemorrhagic fever. Which of the following investigations is beneficial for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with dengue haemorrhagic fever, presenting four days, following onset of illness NS1 antigen would be the preferred test for diagnosis.
  • In case the patient presents after five days following the onset of symptoms the test of choice would be IgM ELISA.
  • Serological tests, such as IgM ELISA, are performed after day 5 when dengue viruses and antigens are no longer present in the blood due to the appearance of specific antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 501,506,529-530.

questions.text: A hypopigmented patch which grows initially and stops progressing after sometime is seen in which type of vitiligo?
questions.solution:
• In segmental vitiligo, lesions increase initially (6-12 months) and then remain static.
  • Here the lesions appear only on one side of the body in a limited area- Appears as unilateral macule in a segmented or band shaped pattern.
  • It's less common than non-segmental vitiligo, but it's more common in children, affecting around 3 in 10 children with vitiligo.
  • Acrofacial vitiligo - Generalised Vitiligo predominantly seen periorificially and acral parts.More resisitant to therapy
  • Mixed Vitiligo- Coexistence of non-segmental and segmental vitiligo in same patient.
Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page No 88.34-88.40.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is secreted by the SA node in response to increased blood pressure?
questions.solution:
• In response to raised BP, there is inhibition of sympathetic system and activation of parasympathetic system.
  • And as Acetylcholine is the universal neurotransmitter of PNS it is secreted in the SA node as a response to elevated BP.
Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page No 577-580.

questions.text: Which among the following is a growth-promoting oncogene?
questions.solution:
• FGF (Fibroblast Growth Factor) is a type of growth factors involved in angiogenesis, wound healing, and embryonic development.
  • Some members of the FGF family can act as oncogenes, that is they promote cell proliferation and survival, thus contributing to the development and progression of cancers.
  • TGF beta, p53, PTEN are examples of tumour suppressor genes
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th Edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Which of the following are features of lower motor neuron lesions?
questions.solution:
• Fasciculation, hypotonia, and muscle atrophy our features of a LMN lesion.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 165-166.

choices.text: Most commonly seen between the age of 40 to 60.
Non Erosive arthritis of the joint with sclerosis is seen

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ankylosing spondylitis is true?
questions.solution:
• Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint
  • It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.
  • Usual age of onset is between 15 and 25 years.
  • Clinically patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with excercise.
  • Cardinal and the earliest sign of ankylosing spondylitis is erosion of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Diagnostic criteria:


Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 72-76.

questions.text: A 74 yrs old female presented with a painful,  left eye. On examination, the lOP of her left eye was 52mmHg and right eye 18mmHg. Slit lamp examination reveals deep anterior chamber, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Painful red eyes, increased IOP and presence of a deep anterior chamber is suggestive of secondary open-angle glaucoma - Phacolytic glaucoma.
  • It in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts
  • Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour.
  • Malignant Glaucoma - Seen after Intraocular surgeries such as Trabeculectomy.
  • Fuchs Heterochromic Iridocyclitis- IOP is not usually high.
  • Phacomorphic glaucoma-  Acute Secondary angle closure glaucoma.
Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A.K. Khurana, 7th Edition, Page No 255.

choices.text: Assertion(A) is true but Reason(R) is false
Assertion(A) is false but Reason(R) is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A) - Mycobacterium is detected in sputum samples with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) and NaOH.
Reason(R) - The sputum samples are treated by NAC to liquify the sputum and NaOH to kill contaminating bacteria.
questions.solution:
Sputum sample collection,
Mycobacterium is detected in sputum samples with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) and NaOH where N-acetyl cysteine is used for liquefaction of sputum and NaOH kills the contaminating bacteria. Therefore in the above question both assertion and reason are true.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No  357-358.
